Award.AwardTitle: CRII:SHF: Enabling Technologies for Three Dimensional (3D) Millimeter-Wave Integrated Circuits: Through Silicon Via (TSV) Modeling and Design

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Millimeter-wave (mmW) communications is regarded as an emerging technology to resolve the spectrum shortage issues resulting from the exponential growth of mobile data traffic. This project addresses the fundamental scientific issues and advanced design challenges of the three-dimensional (3D) mmW integrated circuits (ICs) capable of handling very wide system bandwidth required for emerging communication systems. The project will facilitate further advances in 3D integration and broader adoption of this emerging technology in semiconductor manufacturing and electronic design community by offering fundamental understandings in circuit design for beyond ultra-high frequency (UHF) band wireless communications. In addition to technological impact, the PI will develop a broadening participation plan and an educational plan that will immerse students from the underrepresented groups in the field of electronic circuits. Tools and techniques developed in this research will be used for developing and teaching new courses. Outreach activities will span from the high school level up through the graduate level making full use of University Diversity Programs as well as Missouri-Iowa-Nebraska-Kansas Women in Computing Program. Furthermore, the PI will leverage the collaboration with several leading semiconductor companies to set up technical seminars and internship programs for both undergraduate and graduate students.


Three dimensional integration with Through Silicon Vias (TSVs) applied to the mmW mobile broadband wireless communications could offer miniaturization opportunities, performance improvement, and power consumption reduction. One of the most critical components and challenges in 3D ICs is the modeling and design of TSVs. In light of the great promise and design challenges of 3D mmW ICs, this project targets to introducing new ideas, developing system prototypes, as well as a new and transformative direction for the advancement of TSV design at all levels - circuits, systems, and computer-aided design (CAD). The proposed TSV modeling and analysis methodologies could be integrated with existing Electronics Design and Automation (EDA) tools. By investigating one of the key components of mmW ICs, this project attempts to lay a foundation for a practical design methodology for the mmW systems with higher reliability, lower power consumption, reduced delay, and increased system miniaturization.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The outcomes of this project provide promising modeling and design solutions for the through silicon via (TSV), which is one of the most critical components in the three dimensional (3D) integrated circuits (ICs) for millimeter-wave communication applications. The exponential growth in mobile data traffic requires a significantly higher bandwidth (compared to currently allocated spectrum) for future mobile broadband systems. Millimeter-wave communication has emerged as an enabling technology to resolve this spectrum shortage issue. However, current two-dimensional (2D) integrated circuit technology is approaching its physical and material limits. Only way forward is the integration in the third dimension.

This project is streamlined into two interconnected research thrusts. In the first thrust, we focus on introducing an accurate and efficient TSV model for 3D millimeter-wave IC design and analysis. We fabricate a series of test vehicles of well-designed TSVs to experimentally verify the circuit model. In the second thrust, we design TSV structures that could resolve the signal integrity issues at high frequency data transmission for millimeter-wave systems. We analyze the electrical performance of our TSV structures through both simulations and measurements. By investigating one of the key components of millimeter-wave integrated circuits, this project lays a solid foundation for a practical design methodology for the millimeter-wave systems with higher reliability, lower power consumption, reduced delay, and system miniaturization.

In this project, we acquire and test preliminary data, develop collaborations across research disciplines (wireless communication, nano-device etc.), as well as propose new algorithms, approaches, and system prototypes, which together lead to improved capacity to write proposals submitted to other programs in the future. Our proposal titled ?Enabling Brian-like Computing through 3D Neuromorphic Circuits and Systems? received National Science Foundation CISE/CCF/SHF CAREER award in 2018. Furthermore, the work is published in the flagship conferences in the IEEE VLSI, CAD and EMC society (such as DAC, EMC, ISQED, GLSVLSI, and etc.) as well as leading journals in the field (such as TCAD, TEMC, and etc.). Two of the paper have been selected for Best Paper Award Nomination in GLSVLSI 2017 and ISQED 2017.

In this project, we take advantage of the outcome of this project to foster collaboration between industry and academia to enhance the transformative nature of the project. The modeling methodologies is integrated with existing Electronics Design and Automation (EDA) tools. The research outcomes could be of interests to both telecommunication, semiconductor, and EDA industry. During the project, our undergraduate and graduate students have the opportunities to interact with researchers in Intel Corp. and NVidia Inc. Our group has well established collaborations with leading companies and labs, including: Intel (18 publications with 2 Best Paper Award Nomination in GLSVLSI 2017 and ISQED 2017, and 1 3D IC test chip); NVidia (6 publications and 1 interposer test chip). One of the graduate students: Dr. M. Amimul Ehsan, who was working on the project, has been working with Dr. Zhen Zhou in Intel Research Lab since his summer intern in 2015. Dr. M. Amimul Ehsan has graduated with a Ph.D. degree in August 2017. His Ph.D. thesis is: Enabling Technologies for 3D ICs: TSV Modeling and Analysis. Dr. M. Amimul Ehsan joined Intel after his graduation. Furthermore, our research collaborator: Dr. Zhen Zhou has visited our lab and gave a seminar about our collaborative research project on 3D IC on March 6, 2018. During her visit, our undergraduate and graduate students have the opportunities to learn more research opportunities in Intel Corp.

Another important goal of the project is to broaden the participation of individuals from underrepresented groups in computer science and engineering. The research plan is integrated in the education process to promote students? creativity and independent problem solving abilities through the development of application-oriented projects, and through outreach activities. The proposed research involves training of both graduate and undergraduate students in circuit design, computing, electromagnetics, mathematics, and device physics. We make efforts to involve students from underrepresented groups. Undergraduate students are involved in both research and education tasks such as data processing, curriculum and lab development, peer-tutoring, project web-site maintenance, high school outreach events, etc. Each year, Virginia Tech offers an Undergraduate Research Symposium and Poster day. The undergraduate students working on this project participated in presenting their results and findings in this venue. These experiences provide students with significant research and education experiences designed to motivate them to continue their careers in electronics and computing-related areas.
